content.body: It is kind of understandable that SVGRect is not serializable though. It is not a plain object; it has an inner connection to a SVG element. And serializing that across realm boundaries is tricky.
DOMRect is very simple though and could be made serializable.
I believe the spec still says SVGRect is simple but this was a misstep in the spec and they need to change it back to match implementations https://github.com/w3c/svgwg/issues/706
We ran into this in jsdom
Luca Casonato: I guess it's strictly speaking not defined, yeah
content.formatted_body: Luca Casonato: I guess it's strictly speaking not defined, yeah

content.body: Luca Casonato: given that people notice it we might still want to define it though
content.formatted_body: Luca Casonato: given that people notice it we might still want to define it though

content.body: I guess we could. The current spec language makes what Deno does the most obvious thing to do I think, as headers in the inner header list are not concatenated. Chrome and FF both concatenate the headers on the wire it seems. I didn’t check Safari or Cloudflare Workers
And annevk, as for who noticed that: the author of node-fetch. Have received no reports from “regular” users who are not intimately familiar with the fetch spec.
Combining is also tricky for Set-Cookie, though that's tricky anyway atm
Is it possible to request target in `asterisk-form` (`OPTIONS *`) with the fetch (or another) API? Any pointers on history/discussion would be great.
content.formatted_body: Is it possible to request target in asterisk-form (OPTIONS *) with the fetch (or another) API? Any pointers on history/discussion would be great.

content.body: Would it be inaccurate to describe the WebIDL `readonly` keyword as essentially meaning “not assignable”?
